title: Psalms Chapter 26 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Psalms chapter 26 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Psalms Chapter 26 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Psalms Chapter 26.

questions.question: Who is the author of Psalm 26?
questions.correctAnswer: David
questions.explanation: Psalm 26 is titled 'A Psalm of David,' indicating David is the author (Psalms 26:1).

questions.question: According to Psalms 26:1, why does the psalmist say he shall not slide?
options: Because he has trusted in the LORD
questions.correctAnswer: Because he has trusted in the LORD
questions.explanation: The psalmist states he has trusted in the LORD; therefore he shall not slide (Psalms 26:1).

questions.question: What does the psalmist ask the LORD to do in Psalms 26:2?
questions.correctAnswer: Examine and prove him
questions.explanation: The psalmist asks the LORD to examine him, prove him, and try his reins and heart (Psalms 26:2).

questions.question: Fill in the blank from Psalms 26:4: 'I have not sat with ______ persons, neither will I go in with dissemblers.'
questions.correctAnswer: vain
questions.explanation: The psalmist states he has not sat with vain persons nor gone with dissemblers (Psalms 26:4).

questions.question: What does the psalmist hate according to Psalms 26:5?
questions.correctAnswer: The congregation of evil doers
questions.explanation: The psalmist declares hatred for the congregation of evil doers and refuses to sit with the wicked (Psalms 26:5).

questions.question: True or False: The psalmist says he will wash his hands in guilt before the LORD's altar.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: The psalmist says he will wash his hands in innocency before the LORD's altar, not in guilt (Psalms 26:6).

questions.question: Why does the psalmist say he will compass the LORD's altar according to Psalms 26:6?
options: To publish thanksgiving and tell of wondrous works
questions.correctAnswer: To publish thanksgiving and tell of wondrous works
questions.explanation: The psalmist will compass the altar to publish thanksgiving and declare all God's wondrous works (Psalms 26:7).

questions.question: What does the psalmist love according to Psalms 26:8?
options: The habitation of the LORD's house
questions.correctAnswer: The habitation of the LORD's house
questions.explanation: The psalmist says he loves the habitation of God's house and the place where His honor dwells (Psalms 26:8).

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 26:9 says the psalmist wants to be gathered with sinners and bloody men.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: The psalmist prays not to have his soul gathered with sinners nor his life with bloody men (Psalms 26:9).

questions.question: According to Psalms 26:10, what are in the hands of those the psalmist avoids?
questions.correctAnswer: Mischief and bribes
questions.explanation: The psalmist states the hands of sinners are full of mischief and their right hand full of bribes (Psalms 26:10).

questions.question: What does the psalmist say about his walk in Psalms 26:11?
questions.correctAnswer: He will walk in integrity
questions.explanation: The psalmist declares he will walk in his integrity and asks for redemption and mercy (Psalms 26:11).

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 26:12 says the psalmist's foot stands on an uneven place.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: The psalmist says his foot stands in an even place and he will bless the LORD in congregations (Psalms 26:12).

questions.question: In Psalms 26:3, what is before the psalmist's eyes?
questions.correctAnswer: Thy lovingkindness
questions.explanation: The psalmist declares that God's lovingkindness is before his eyes and he has walked in God's truth (Psalms 26:3).

questions.question: Who does the psalmist refuse to sit with according to Psalms 26:4?
questions.correctAnswer: Vain persons and dissemblers
questions.explanation: The psalmist states he has not sat with vain persons nor gone in with dissemblers (Psalms 26:4).

questions.question: Fill in the blank from Psalms 26:12: 'My foot standeth in an ______ place: in the congregations will I bless the LORD.'
questions.correctAnswer: even
questions.explanation: The psalmist says his foot stands in an even place and he will bless the LORD in congregations (Psalms 26:12).

medium.title: Psalms Chapter 26 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Psalms Chapter 26 to real-life situations.

questions.question: How does Psalms 26 teach us about maintaining integrity in our daily walk with God?
options: By walking in integrity and trusting the LORD
By surrounding ourselves only with friends
questions.correctAnswer: By walking in integrity and trusting the LORD
questions.explanation: Psalms 26:1 emphasizes walking in integrity and trusting in the LORD as the foundation for not slipping. This is supported by verses 3 and 11 which speak of walking in truth and integrity.

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling with temptation to join those who do evil. Based on Psalms 26, what biblical truth would you share?
options: Avoid sitting with vain persons and evildoers
Join them to understand their ways
Ignore the problem and it will go away
Pretend to agree but do not follow
questions.correctAnswer: Avoid sitting with vain persons and evildoers
questions.explanation: Psalms 26:4-5 shows the psalmist's refusal to associate with vain persons and evil doers, teaching the importance of separation from wicked influences.

questions.question: What role does prayer and self-examination play in spiritual discipline according to Psalms 26?
options: Ask God to examine and prove your heart
Rely solely on others to judge your heart
questions.correctAnswer: Ask God to examine and prove your heart
questions.explanation: Psalms 26:2 calls on the LORD to examine and prove the psalmist's reins and heart, emphasizing the importance of personal spiritual reflection and accountability.

questions.question: How does Psalms 26 teach us about honesty and cleansing in our worship life?
options: Wash hands in innocence before approaching God’s altar
questions.correctAnswer: Wash hands in innocence before approaching God’s altar
questions.explanation: Verse 6 shows the psalmist's commitment to innocence symbolized by washing hands before approaching the altar, teaching that purity and honesty are essential in worship.

questions.question: What does Psalms 26 say about sharing the testimony of God's works?
options: Publish thanksgiving and tell of God’s wondrous works
questions.correctAnswer: Publish thanksgiving and tell of God’s wondrous works
questions.explanation: Verse 7 encourages proclaiming thanksgiving and telling of all God's wondrous works, emphasizing evangelism and being a witness.

questions.question: How does the psalmist express his love for the place of God’s honor?
options: By loving the habitation of God’s house
By neglecting the house of God
By focusing only on personal spirituality
questions.correctAnswer: By loving the habitation of God’s house
questions.explanation: Verse 8 clearly states the psalmist’s love for the habitation of God's house and the place where His honor dwells, teaching the value of fellowship and reverence for sacred spaces.

questions.question: According to Psalms 26, how should believers view being associated with sinners and violent men?
options: Do not gather your soul with sinners nor life with bloody men
Blend in with sinners for acceptance
questions.correctAnswer: Do not gather your soul with sinners nor life with bloody men
questions.explanation: Verses 9 and 10 warn against being gathered with sinners and those whose hands are full of mischief, teaching the importance of avoiding ungodly associations.

questions.question: How does the psalmist describe his confidence in God’s mercy and redemption?
options: Walking in integrity and asking for mercy and redemption
Relying on his own strength alone
questions.correctAnswer: Walking in integrity and asking for mercy and redemption
questions.explanation: Verse 11 shows the psalmist’s confidence in walking in integrity and calls upon God to redeem and be merciful, illustrating humility and trust.

questions.question: What does Psalms 26 say about standing firm in the community of believers?
options: My foot standeth in an even place; in congregations I bless the LORD
Do not participate in the community
questions.correctAnswer: My foot standeth in an even place; in congregations I bless the LORD
questions.explanation: Verse 12 highlights the importance of standing firm in the community of believers and blessing the LORD together, emphasizing fellowship and worship.

questions.question: True or False: According to Psalms 26, the psalmist trusts in the LORD which ensures he will not slip.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Psalms 26:1 states the psalmist has trusted in the LORD and therefore shall not slide, showing trust in God’s protection.

questions.question: True or False: The psalmist claims to have sat with wicked people and dissemblers according to Psalms 26.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Verses 4 and 5 explicitly state the psalmist has not sat with vain persons or wicked men and hates the congregation of evildoers.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: "I will wash mine hands in ________; so will I compass thine altar, O LORD."
questions.correctAnswer: innocency
questions.explanation: Verse 6 states the psalmist will wash his hands in innocency before approaching the altar, signifying purity.

questions.question: How does the psalmist describe his heart’s attitude toward God’s lovingkindness?
options: Keeping lovingkindness before his eyes and walking in God’s truth
questions.correctAnswer: Keeping lovingkindness before his eyes and walking in God’s truth
questions.explanation: Verse 3 describes that the psalmist keeps God’s lovingkindness before his eyes and walks in His truth, highlighting faithfulness.

questions.question: What practical lesson about honesty in work and daily life can be drawn from Psalms 26?
options: Walk in integrity and avoid taking bribes
questions.correctAnswer: Walk in integrity and avoid taking bribes
questions.explanation: Verses 9 and 10 condemn those with hands full of mischief and bribes, teaching the importance of honesty and integrity in life.

questions.question: Based on Psalms 26, how should believers show gratitude in their spiritual life?
options: By publishing thanksgiving and telling of God’s wondrous works
By only thanking God when convenient
By focusing on material blessings only
questions.correctAnswer: By publishing thanksgiving and telling of God’s wondrous works
questions.explanation: Verse 7 encourages thanksgiving and sharing God's wondrous works, teaching gratitude expressed through testimony.

hard.title: Psalms Chapter 26 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Psalms Chapter 26.

questions.question: In Psalms 26:1, what reason does David give for his confidence that he 'shall not slide'?
options: Because he has walked in integrity
Because he has conquered his enemies
questions.correctAnswer: Because he has walked in integrity
questions.explanation: Psalms 26:1 states that David trusts in the LORD and has walked in integrity, which is why he believes he shall not slide.

questions.question: What does David ask God to 'examine' and 'prove' in Psalms 26:2?
questions.correctAnswer: His reins and his heart
questions.explanation: The verse specifically mentions that David asks the LORD to examine his reins (kidneys, figuratively inner being) and heart, indicating a deep personal scrutiny (Psalms 26:2).

questions.question: Which quality does David claim to have walked in, according to Psalms 26:3?
questions.correctAnswer: Thy truth
questions.explanation: David declares that he has walked in God's truth, emphasizing faithfulness and steadfastness in God's covenant (Psalms 26:3).

questions.question: In Psalms 26:4-5, David refuses to associate with certain types of people. Who are they?
questions.correctAnswer: Vain persons and dissemblers
questions.explanation: David explicitly states he has not sat with vain persons nor will he go in with dissemblers, and he hates the congregation of evildoers (Psalms 26:4-5).

questions.question: What symbolic action does David declare in Psalms 26:6 to demonstrate his innocence?
questions.correctAnswer: Washing his hands
questions.explanation: David says he will wash his hands in innocency to symbolize his purity before approaching God's altar (Psalms 26:6).

questions.question: What is the purpose of David compassing God's altar as mentioned in Psalms 26:6-7?
options: To publish thanksgiving and tell of God's wondrous works
To pray for victory in battle
questions.correctAnswer: To publish thanksgiving and tell of God's wondrous works
questions.explanation: David intends to proclaim thanksgiving and recount the marvelous deeds of God when he surrounds His altar (Psalms 26:7).

questions.question: According to Psalms 26:8, what specific location does David express love for?
questions.correctAnswer: The habitation of God's house
questions.explanation: David loves the place where God's honor dwells, the habitation of His house, which is the temple or sanctuary (Psalms 26:8).

questions.question: In Psalms 26:9, David requests that his soul not be gathered with which groups?
questions.correctAnswer: Sinners and bloody men
questions.explanation: David prays that his soul not be gathered with sinners or those who shed blood, underscoring his desire to remain pure (Psalms 26:9).

questions.question: How does Psalms 26:10 describe the hands of the wicked?
questions.correctAnswer: Full of mischief and bribes
questions.explanation: The verse highlights that the wicked have hands filled with mischief and their right hands with bribes, indicating corruption (Psalms 26:10).

questions.question: What repeated theme is evident in both Psalms 26:1 and Psalms 26:11?
questions.correctAnswer: Walking in integrity
questions.explanation: David asserts his integrity as a basis for his confidence and plea for redemption in both verses (Psalms 26:1 and 26:11).

questions.question: What does David ask God to do for him in Psalms 26:11?
options: Redeem and be merciful unto him
questions.correctAnswer: Redeem and be merciful unto him
questions.explanation: David petitions God to redeem him and show mercy, reflecting his dependence on divine grace (Psalms 26:11).

questions.question: In Psalms 26:12, where does David declare he will bless the LORD?
questions.correctAnswer: In the congregations
questions.explanation: David states his foot stands in an even place and that he will bless the LORD in the congregations, indicating public worship (Psalms 26:12).

questions.question: True or False: In Psalms 26:5, David states that he will join the wicked congregation to understand them better.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: David clearly says he hates the congregation of evildoers and will not sit with the wicked (Psalms 26:5).

questions.question: Which literary device is most evident in the structure of Psalms 26, considering the movement from personal integrity to public worship?
questions.correctAnswer: Chiasm
questions.explanation: The Psalm exhibits chiastic structure, moving from David's personal integrity and examination to his public declaration of praise and worship, then back to integrity (seen in verses 1-3 and 11-12 framing the middle).

questions.question: The Hebrew term translated as 'reins' in Psalms 26:2 refers to which concept in biblical anthropology?
options: The inner being or kidneys, seat of emotions
questions.correctAnswer: The inner being or kidneys, seat of emotions
questions.explanation: In Hebrew thought, 'reins' (kidneys) represent the inner person or emotions, so David asks God to test his innermost thoughts (Psalms 26:2).

theological.title: Psalms Chapter 26 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Psalms Chapter 26 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: According to Psalms 26:1, what reason does David give for his confidence that he 'shall not slide'?
options: He has walked in integrity and trusted in the LORD
He has a large following of righteous people
He has memorized the Law perfectly
questions.correctAnswer: He has walked in integrity and trusted in the LORD
questions.explanation: David states in Psalms 26:1 that because he has walked in integrity and trusted in the LORD, he shall not slide. This reflects the biblical teaching about the security of the believer who trusts God (Proverbs 10:9; Psalm 37:23-24; John 10:28-29; Philippians 1:6).

questions.question: What does David ask God to do in Psalms 26:2 to demonstrate his faithfulness?
options: Examine and prove his heart and reins
Send him a sign from heaven
questions.correctAnswer: Examine and prove his heart and reins
questions.explanation: David requests God to examine and prove his inner being (heart and reins), reflecting the biblical theme that God knows and tests the thoughts and intents of the heart (Jeremiah 17:10; 1 Chronicles 28:9; Hebrews 4:12; Psalm 139:23-24).

questions.question: In Psalms 26:4, what kind of company does David refuse to join?
questions.correctAnswer: Vain persons and dissemblers
questions.explanation: David rejects sitting with vain persons and dissemblers, meaning those who are empty-hearted and deceitful. This reflects the biblical teaching that believers should avoid fellowship with the wicked (1 Corinthians 15:33; Psalm 1:1; Proverbs 13:20; 2 Corinthians 6:14).

questions.question: What is the attitude of David toward the congregation of evil doers as stated in Psalms 26:5?
options: He hates them and will not sit with the wicked
questions.correctAnswer: He hates them and will not sit with the wicked
questions.explanation: David expresses hatred toward the congregation of evil doers and refuses to associate with them, demonstrating the biblical principle of separating from persistent sin and wickedness (Psalm 1:5; Proverbs 4:14-15; 2 Timothy 3:1-5; Revelation 21:8).

questions.question: What symbolic action does David say he will perform in Psalms 26:6 to show his innocence?
questions.correctAnswer: Wash his hands in innocency
questions.explanation: David declares he will wash his hands in innocency, symbolizing purity and righteousness before God. This action corresponds with biblical imagery of innocence and purity (Psalm 73:13; Matthew 27:24; Exodus 30:18; Job 31:6).

questions.question: What is the purpose David gives in Psalms 26:7 for compassing the LORD's altar?
options: To publish with thanksgiving and tell of God's wondrous works
To demand justice against his enemies
questions.correctAnswer: To publish with thanksgiving and tell of God's wondrous works
questions.explanation: David aims to proclaim thanksgiving and declare God's wondrous works, highlighting the biblical theme of worship and testimony of God's acts (Psalm 107:22; Psalm 95:2; Psalm 100:4; Hebrews 13:15).

questions.question: In Psalms 26:8, what does David say he loves?
options: The habitation of God's house and the place where His honor dwells
questions.correctAnswer: The habitation of God's house and the place where His honor dwells
questions.explanation: David expresses love for the dwelling place of God's presence and honor, reflecting the biblical emphasis on reverence for God's sanctuary (Psalm 84:1-2; 1 Kings 8:27; John 4:21-24; Hebrews 10:21-22).

questions.question: What plea does David make in Psalms 26:9 regarding his soul and life?
options: Gather not my soul with sinners nor my life with bloody men
Deliver me from the hand of the enemy
Grant me long life and prosperity
Reveal your will to me in dreams
questions.correctAnswer: Gather not my soul with sinners nor my life with bloody men
questions.explanation: David asks God not to associate his soul and life with sinners and violent men, expressing a desire for holiness and separation from judgment (Psalm 1:5-6; Proverbs 3:33; Isaiah 59:2; 1 Corinthians 6:9-10).

questions.question: According to Psalms 26:10, what characterizes the hands of the wicked?
options: Their hands are full of mischief and their right hand full of bribes
Their hands are clean and just
questions.correctAnswer: Their hands are full of mischief and their right hand full of bribes
questions.explanation: The wicked are described as having hands full of mischief and bribes, illustrating corruption and injustice (Exodus 23:8; Proverbs 17:23; Micah 7:3; Isaiah 1:23).

questions.question: In Psalms 26:11, what does David affirm about his own conduct?
options: He will walk in integrity and asks for redemption and mercy
He will conquer his enemies by force
He will accumulate wealth and honor
He will remain silent in affliction
questions.correctAnswer: He will walk in integrity and asks for redemption and mercy
questions.explanation: David affirms walking in integrity and seeks God's redemption and mercy, reflecting the biblical doctrine of walking in righteousness and relying on God's grace (Psalm 15:2; Micah 6:8; Ephesians 2:8-9; Lamentations 3:22-23).

questions.question: What is described about David’s footing in Psalms 26:12, and what will he do in the congregations?
options: His foot stands in an even place and he will bless the LORD
His foot falters and he will seek refuge
His foot is swift to flee and he will hide
His foot is heavy and he will mourn
questions.correctAnswer: His foot stands in an even place and he will bless the LORD
questions.explanation: David states his foot stands on firm ground and he will bless the LORD in the congregation, symbolizing stability in faith and public worship (Psalm 40:2; Psalm 16:8; Hebrews 10:25; Romans 12:11).

questions.question: How does Psalms 26 reveal the attribute of God's justice in relation to the psalmist's request?
options: David asks God to judge him because he has walked in integrity
David asks God to punish his enemies without mercy
David ignores God's justice and focuses only on mercy
David demands that God prove himself by miracles
questions.correctAnswer: David asks God to judge him because he has walked in integrity
questions.explanation: The psalmist appeals to God's justice as he requests judgment because of his integrity, emphasizing God's righteous judgment (Psalm 26:1; Psalm 7:8; Romans 2:2; Revelation 19:11).

questions.question: In Psalms 26, what theological significance does the act of 'washing hands in innocency' carry in relation to Christological themes?
options: It symbolizes purity and points forward to Christ's atoning righteousness
It is a ritual that only priests could perform
It is a metaphor for baptism by the Holy Spirit
It indicates a legalistic approach to salvation
questions.correctAnswer: It symbolizes purity and points forward to Christ's atoning righteousness
questions.explanation: The washing of hands in innocence symbolizes purity and can be seen as prefiguring Christ's atoning righteousness that cleanses sin (Psalm 26:6; Isaiah 1:16; Hebrews 9:14; 1 John 1:7-9; Romans 5:9).

questions.question: How does Psalms 26:8 contribute to biblical ecclesiology regarding the believer's relationship with the house of God?
options: David expresses love for God's house, affirming the importance of worship and God's dwelling among His people
David prefers solitude over communal worship
David disregards the temple as unnecessary
David focuses solely on personal prayer
questions.correctAnswer: David expresses love for God's house, affirming the importance of worship and God's dwelling among His people
questions.explanation: David's love for the habitation of God's house highlights the biblical doctrine of the church as God's dwelling place and the importance of corporate worship (Psalm 26:8; 1 Timothy 3:15; Hebrews 10:25; John 14:23; Acts 2:42).

questions.question: What does the psalmist's refusal to 'sit with the wicked' teach about holiness and separation in the life of the believer?
options: Believers are called to separate from evil influences to maintain holiness
Believers should judge and condemn sinners openly
Believers must isolate themselves from society
Believers are exempt from associating with anyone outside the church
questions.correctAnswer: Believers are called to separate from evil influences to maintain holiness
questions.explanation: David's refusal to associate with the wicked teaches the biblical principle of separation from evil to uphold holiness (Psalm 26:5; 2 Corinthians 6:14-17; Ephesians 5:11; 1 Thessalonians 5:22; Romans 12:2).
